@I501496@.narrative: John Thompson Grisham was born September 9, 1791, on Dumplin Creek, Jefferson County, Tennessee — one of the earliest settled frontier communities in the state, site of the 1785 Treaty of Dumplin Creek with the Cherokee. He died August 1873, having lived through the entire arc of Tennessee's transformation from Cherokee country to settled state. He was the grandfather of Cassandra A. Grisham.

@I501497@.narrative: Mary Polly R. Corbett was born August 26, 1792, in Jefferson County, Tennessee, and died April 10, 1884. She married John Thompson Grisham. The Corbett family was part of the early Tennessee pioneer community in the Dumplin Creek watershed.

@I501128@.narrative: William Daniel Grisham was born September 9, 1837, in McMinn County, Tennessee — a county in the Tennessee Valley where the Trail of Tears had passed directly through in 1838, just after his birth. He was a farmer and died April 12, 1900. He was the father of Cassandra A. Grisham.

@I501129@.narrative: Mary Ann Witt was born June 10, 1844, in Dandridge, Jefferson County, Tennessee — in the Great Smoky Mountain foothills, one of the oldest European communities in the state. She died in 1880, a farm wife (Keeping House). She married William Daniel Grisham and her daughter Cassandra would marry Lorenzo Chambliss in Texas.

@I501504@.narrative: James Randolph Witt was born August 23, 1813, in Dandridge, Jefferson County, Tennessee, and died in 1895. He was the father of Mary Ann Witt. The Witt family was part of the long-established Tennessee mountain community around Dandridge on the French Broad River.

@I501505@.narrative: Delilah Harkrider was born March 10, 1815, in Virginia, and died November 17, 1861. She married James Randolph Witt. The Harkrider family's Virginia roots connect to the broader Scots-Irish and Anglo-American migration from Virginia into Tennessee.

@I500976@.narrative: Jesse Jerome Gunter was born October 1, 1896, in Montague County, Texas — a North Texas frontier community that had only been opened to settlement after the Red River War of 1874-75. He died January 27, 1964. He married Bertha M. Chambless of the same county. His mother Annette V. McCully and father William Thomas Gunter had both been born in the same area, establishing the family as one of Montague County's settler generation.

@I500977@.narrative: Bertha M. Chambless was born July 2, 1900, in Montague County, Texas, and died January 9, 1953. She was the daughter of Lorenzo Dow Chambliss and Cassandra A. Grisham. Her father Lorenzo had been born in Houston County, Texas in 1868 and moved to Montague County; her mother died when Bertha was just nine months old. She married Jesse Jerome Gunter.

@I501185@.narrative: William Akin was born in 1790 in North Carolina and died November 29, 1883 — a remarkable 93 years old. He was the father of Rebecca Akin who married Alexander Pinkerton. The Akin family traced through North Carolina and Pennsylvania, part of the Scots-Irish migration network.

@I501186@.narrative: Rebecca 'Becky' McKinney was born in 1789 in Lincoln County, Kentucky — at the very beginning of Kentucky's settlement era, just a decade after Daniel Boone's road opened the wilderness. She died October 13, 1850. She married William Akin. Her McKinney family had New Jersey colonial roots.

@I501368@.narrative: James Akin was born approximately 1755 in Pennsylvania, and died approximately 1822. He was the father of William Akin. Pennsylvania in the 1750s was the most ethnically diverse colony in British America, and the Akin family was part of the Scots-Irish community that would push south and west in the Revolutionary era.

@I501369@.narrative: Mary Murphey was born March 19, 1758, in Culpeper County, Virginia, and died in 1822. She married James Akin. The Murphey family was part of the Scots-Irish Virginia Piedmont community.

@I501381@.narrative: Daniel McKinney was born in 1742 in Somerset County, Province of New Jersey — a colonial county on the Raritan River, home to Dutch, English, and Scots-Irish communities. He died May 19, 1809. He was the father of Rebecca 'Becky' McKinney who married William Akin. New Jersey's land riots of the 1740s had disrupted his county, and the Revolution brought military action directly to Somerset County.

@I501382@.narrative: Mercy Blatchley was born March 31, 1745, in Somerset County, New Jersey, and died July 26, 1825. She married Daniel McKinney. The Blatchley name was associated with Quaker communities in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

@I501412@.narrative: William Lazarus was born in 1767 in Rowan County, North Carolina, and died in 1825. He was the father of Charlotte Young (born 1800, Rockingham County) — wait, actually William Lazarus appears in the data as Charlotte Young's father-in-law or Randolph Hinkle line. He was part of the Rowan County Carolina Piedmont community.

@I501413@.narrative: Nancy Polly Randal was born in 1770 in North Carolina, and died in 1820. She was part of the Rowan County community in the Carolina Piedmont. William Lazarus and Nancy Polly Randal were connected to the Hinkle-Boyd lineage through the Carolina Piedmont migration network.

@I500005@.narrative: Charles Homer Britton was born November 26, 1922, in Purves, Erath County, Texas — a small farming community in the Western Cross Timbers region, where post-oak woodland alternates with rolling prairie. He was a farmer and died December 8, 2004. He married Bertha Flois Gunter and raised their daughter Lula Annetta Britton in the Texas High Plains. His ancestors had arrived in Hamilton County in the 1880s from Alabama and the Deep South, drawn by cheap frontier land and the promise of Texas cotton farming. Charles witnessed the boll weevil's devastation of Texas cotton, the Dust Bowl, World War II, and the transformation of Texas agriculture from cotton to diversified farming and ranching across his 82 years.

@I500004@.narrative: Bertha Flois Gunter was born October 12, 1922, in Texas — the daughter of Jesse Jerome Gunter and Bertha M. Chambless of Montague County, North Texas. She was a homemaker and died September 17, 2012 — at 89 years old, one of the longest-lived ancestors in the tree. She married Charles Homer Britton and raised her family in West Texas. Her Gunter and Chambliss ancestors had come from South Carolina, Alabama, Missouri, and Arkansas, all converging on the North Texas frontier in the 1870s-1880s just after the Comanche wars ended.

@I500979@.narrative: Albert Green Britton Jr. was born December 20, 1888, in Carlton, Hamilton County, Texas — in the Western Cross Timbers hill country that his father Albert Green Britton had reached after the post-Civil War exodus from Alabama. He died March 11, 1941. He married Clara Ann Shaffer of nearby Fairy, Hamilton County. Carlton was a small farming town that briefly boomed when the Stephenville, North and South Texas Railway arrived in 1907. The Cross Timbers region's thin soils and alternating woodland and prairie supported mixed farming of cotton, grain, and cattle.

@I500980@.narrative: Clara Ann Shaffer was born October 2, 1890, in Fairy, Hamilton County, Texas — a small community that received its charming name in 1884, honoring Fairy Fort Phelps, the petite daughter of a Confederate veteran. She died October 2, 1978, on her 88th birthday. Her parents John Adam Shaffer from Tennessee and Lucinda Mae Lula Thornton from Comanche County had settled in Hamilton County as part of the great post-Civil War migration from the South and border states. She married Albert Green Britton Jr. and together they farmed the Cross Timbers country. A 1867 Comanche attack on a Hamilton County school, in which the teacher was killed, was still living memory in her family's stories.

@I501239@.narrative: George Cranfield was the father of Elizabeth Cranfield (b. 1816, Leeds, Yorkshire), who married William Jenkinson Sr. He was thus part of the Leeds industrial community in the early nineteenth century, living through the most explosive phase of Yorkshire's transformation from wool-market town to industrial giant.

@I501911@.narrative: Petri Schumacher lived in Luxembourg — likely in Frisange or the surrounding Esch-sur-Alzette area, given that his daughter Marie Régine Schumacher was born in Frisange in 1753. His dates are unrecorded. The Schumacher name (meaning 'shoemaker' in German) was common across Luxembourg's German-speaking communities.

@I501912@.narrative: Barbara Vestque lived in Luxembourg, her dates unrecorded. She was the mother of Marie Régine Schumacher (b. 1753, Frisange), who married Joannes Lorang of Frisange and continued the family in this southern Luxembourg border village.

@I501486@.narrative: Anne Nee was born in 1702 and died November 5, 1750 — likely in Alzingen, Hesperange, Luxembourg, given that she married Jean Gaasch, an Alzingen resident. Her surname 'Nee' may indicate her maiden name was unrecorded (née meaning 'born as'), or it was her actual surname. She was the mother of Nicolas Gaasch (b. 1717) and thus great-great-grandmother of the emigrant Joannes Gaasch who crossed to Iowa in 1848.

@I501561@.narrative: Magdalena NU was born in 1696 and married Mathias Thinnes in Niederanven, Luxembourg. The surname 'NU' in records typically indicates the maiden name was unknown or not recorded — a common situation in seventeenth and early eighteenth century parish records. She was the mother of Franz Thinnes (b. c.1725, Hostert, Niederanven).

@I501937@.narrative: Margaretha Herber married Johann Hastert of Steinheim, Echternach, Luxembourg. Her dates are unrecorded. She was the mother of Angela Hastert (b. 1682, Steinheim), who married Petrus Goden of Bitburg and continued the family line in the Sauer River valley.

@I502000@.narrative:
Joannes Gaasch (recorded as 'Gausch' in the Latin parish records) lived in Bivingen (Bivange), a small village in the commune of Roeser, southern Luxembourg. He is the probable father of Jean Gaasch (born c. 1698), making him the earliest Gaasch ancestor identified through primary source research. His wife's name was Margaretha, maiden name not yet established, though a woman named Margaretha Goesch appears in the Bivingen community as an unmarried godmother in March 1692 — possibly the same person before her marriage to Joannes.

Joannes is confirmed in the Roeser parish register on three occasions: as godfather for a neighbor's child on April 18, 1695; as father of son Nicolaus baptized March 27, 1699; and again as godfather for another Bivingen neighbor's child in April 1699. His repeated selection as godfather indicates he was a trusted and respected member of the tight-knit Bivingen community.

Bivingen in the late 17th century was a small agricultural village of perhaps a dozen families, including the Gaasch, Godesch, Hemmer, Schumesch, Eder, Peters, and Klensch families — all of whom appear repeatedly as godparents for each other's children. The village sat in the gentle rolling farmland south of Luxembourg City, within the ancient parish of Roeser. Joannes would have farmed the same fields his neighbors did, lived through the Nine Years' War and the War of the Spanish Succession, and watched Luxembourg pass from Spanish to French to Austrian hands — distant political upheavals that touched rural village life mainly through taxation and the occasional passage of troops.

His estimated birth year is approximately 1665–1675, based on his activity as godfather in 1695 implying full adulthood. His death date is unknown. A Wilhelm Gaasch of Bivingen died November 22, 1725 — possibly Joannes's brother — confirming the family remained in Bivingen into the 1720s.

@I502002@.narrative:
Nicolaus Gaasch was baptized on March 27, 1699, in Bivingen (Bivange), in the commune of Roeser, southern Luxembourg — one of the clearest documented events in this branch of the family's early history. His baptism entry in the Roeser parish register reads: 'Joannis Gausch et Margaretha Conjugum ex Bivingen filius Nicolaus natus est et baptizatus 27 Marty Anno 1699,' confirming his parents as Joannes Gaasch and his wife Margaretha.

Nicolaus was the younger brother of Jean Gaasch (born c. 1698), who would later settle in the neighboring village of Alzingen. While Jean moved west to Alzingen, Nicolaus appears to have maintained ties to the Bivingen-Alzingen area as well — a man named Nicolao Gaasch ex Alzingen served as godfather for Jean's grandson Joannes Gaasch in a November 1743 Hesperange baptism record, almost certainly this same Nicolaus decades later. His further life — marriage, children, and death — has not yet been traced in surviving records.

@I502001@.narrative:
Margaretha Gaasch (née unknown) was the wife of Joannes Gaasch of Bivingen and the probable mother of Jean Gaasch (born c. 1698). She is confirmed in the Roeser parish register in the March 1699 baptism entry for her son Nicolaus: 'Joannis Gausch et Margaretha Conjugum ex Bivingen filius Nicolaus natus est et baptizatus 27 Marty Anno 1699.'

Her maiden name has not been established from existing records. The most promising lead is a woman named Margaretha Goesch who appears in the Bivingen community as an unmarried godmother in March 1692 — before she would have married Joannes. In these Luxembourg records, women appear under their husband's surname after marriage, so an unmarried Margaretha Goesch in 1692 who later disappears from the records under that name could well be the same woman who became Margaretha Gaasch. The Goesch family was a distinct but closely connected Bivingen family — Nicolaus Godesch and his wife Anna are confirmed neighbors of the Gaasches throughout the 1690s.

Her marriage to Joannes likely took place around 1693–1695, based on the birth of their first known child approximately 1697–1698. The marriage record has not been found in the Roeser parish register, suggesting either that it was one of the many marriages not recorded in this primarily baptismal register, or that Margaretha came from a neighboring parish whose records do not survive for this period. The Hesperange register, which would cover Alzingen and surrounding villages, only begins in 1717.
